definition: conceived or made without regard for reason or reality
sentences: *Absurd* claims of having been abducted by UFO's.

definition: showing or marked by a lack of good sense or judgement
sentences: An *absurd* rule that bicycles are not allowed in the park.

definition: a state of great suffering of body or mind
sentences: As a new teacher, she was in real *anguish* over the decision to report the cheating.

definition: deep sadness especially for the loss of someone or something loved
sentences: Words can't express my *anguish* at losing my cat.

definition: to cause persistent suffering to
sentences: She was *anguished* by the fear that her sons would die in the war.

definition: to feel deep sadness or mental pain
sentences: I *anguished* over the loss of my father for years afterwards.

definition: having much high-spirited energy and movement
sentences: A *brisk* exercise that many athletes use to warm up.

definition: moving, proceeding, or acting with great speed
sentences: Moved at a *brisk* walk through the exhibit.

definition: marked by much life, movement, or activity
sentences: *Brisk* trading on the stock market.

definition: facial appearance regarded as an indication of mood or feeling
sentences: A pleasant *countenance* that puts visitors at ease.

definition: to have a favorable opinion of
sentences: I don't *countenance* such behavior in children of any age.

definition: having or showing a lack of interest or concern
sentences: The city's philistines, naturally *disinterested* in art, voted to cut the museum's budget.

definition: marked by justice, honesty, and freedom from bias.
sentences: A judge who is widely respected for his *disinterested* decisions.

definition: a state of being aware
sentences: Took *heed* of the student's learning disability so as to arrive at reasonable expectations for him.

definition: strict attentiveness to what one is doing
sentences: Pay *heed* to what you're doing with that knife while you're talking.

definition: to take notice of and be guided by
sentences: If we had *heeded* the ranger's advice, we might not have gotten lost.

definition: to pay attention especially through the act of hearing
sentences: That boy never *heeds* when I caution him about running with his shoelaces untied.

definition: to be the business or affair of
sentences: This isn't something that *involves* you, so don't worry about it.

definition: to have as part of a whole
sentences: A tragic play usually *involves* a number of plot devices, including the hero's fatal flaw.

definition: to hold the attention of
sentences: Her blissful daydream so completely *involved* her that she never heard the knock on the door.

definition: to surround or cover closely
sentences: A mind that was deeply *involved* in doubt about his wife's fidelity.

definition: being in a situation where one is likely to meet with harm
sentences: Because of his frail constitution, he's *liable* to diseases.

definition: being the one who must meet an obligation or suffer the consequences for failing to do so
sentences: The owner of a pet is *liable* for any damage that that pet might do.

definition: a small uneven mass
sentences: She dumped a *lump* of clay on the table and started to sculpt.

definition: a small rounded mass of swollen tissue
sentences: I got a good-sized *lump* on my head from that fall.

definition: an abnormal mass of tissue
sentences: Advised by her doctor to examine her breasts regularly for unusual *lumps*.

definition: to bring together in one body or place
sentences: When we *lumped* all of our pocket change together, we found that we had just enough a buy a carton of ice cream.

definition: something extraordinary or surprising
sentences: That new electric car really is a *marvel*.

definition: the following of a custom, rule, or law
sentences: The *observance* of this family trandition would make your grandmother very happy.

definition: an oft-repeated action of series of actions performed in accordance with tradition or a set of rules
sentences: Some religions require very specific *observances* on holy days.

definition: to present a false appearance of
sentences: *Professed* friendship while secretly plotting revenge.

definition: to state clearly and strongly
sentences: The lonely woman *professed* her love in a series of letters to the soldier.

definition: to state as a fact usually forcefully
sentences: He *professed* his innocence to anyone who would listen.

definition: to drive back
sentences: The defenders *repelled* the attacking army after several hours of fierce fighting.

definition: to refuse to give in to
sentences: *Repelled* the temptation to stay out late and call in sick the next day.

definition: being the one who must meet an obligation or suffer the consequences for failing to do so
sentences: The state laws hold pet owners *responsible* for any damage or injury done by improperly restrained animals.

definition: worthy of one's trust
sentences: Our regular babysitter is very *responsible*.

definition: to make more pleasant to the taste by adding something intensely flavored
sentences: The chef *seasoned* the vegetables as soon as they came out of the oven

definition: the area or space occupied by or intended for something
sentences: This field is the intended *site* for a new shopping mall.

definition: basic or main, standard or regular
sentences: The summer *staple* item this year is any garment that is off the shoulder.;Her latest film is the *staple* offering of action and comedy that we have come to expect.

definition: the main or greater part of something as distinguished from its subordinate parts
sentences: Reading is the very *staple* of a person's education.

definition: to continue to declare to be true or proper despite opposition or objections
sentences: Determined to *uphold* her views in the face of all chanllenges.

definition: to hold up or serve as a foundation for
sentences: An entablature *upheld* by a series of gracefully slender columns.

definition: to move from a lower to a higher place or position
sentences: Worshippers *upheld* their joined hands and sang the praises of the Lord.
